revision.text:
{{For|others called Glen or Glenn Murray|Glen Murray (disambiguation)}} {{pp-vandalism|expiry=19:59, 1 April 2019|small=yes}} {{Use British English|date=October 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2018}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Glenn Murray | image = Glen Murray 21-07-2012.jpg | image_size = 200 | caption = Murray playing for [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] in 2012 | fullname = Glenn Murray<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/612828 |title=Updated squads for 2017/18 Premier League confirmed |publisher=Premier League |date=2 February 2018 |accessdate=10 February 2018}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1983|9|25|df=y}}<ref name=Hugman1011>{{Cite book |editor-first=Barry J. |editor-last=Hugman |title=The PFA Footballers' Who's Who 2010–11 |date=2010 |publisher=Mainstream |isbn=978-1-84596-601-0 |page=301}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Maryport]], England | height = {{convert|1.83|m|order=flip}}<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.brightonandhovealbion.com/teams/first-team/forward/glenn-murray/ |title=Glenn Murray |publisher=Brighton & Hove Albion F.C. |accessdate=9 December 2018}}</ref> | position = [[Forward (association football)|Striker]] | currentclub = [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] | clubnumber = 17 | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = | years1 = 2002–2004 | clubs1 = [[Workington A.F.C.|Workington Reds]] | caps1 = | goals1 = | years2 = 2004 | clubs2 = [[Wilmington Hammerheads FC|Wilmington Hammerheads]] | caps2 = 14 | goals2 = 3 | years3 = 2004 | clubs3 = [[Barrow A.F.C.|Barrow]] | caps3 = 6 | goals3 = 6 | years4 = 2004–2007 | clubs4 = [[Carlisle United F.C.|Carlisle United]] | caps4 = 46 | goals4 = 5 | years5 = 2006 | clubs5 = → [[Stockport County F.C.|Stockport County]] (loan) | caps5 = 11 | goals5 = 3 | years6 = 2006–2007 | clubs6 = → [[Rochdale A.F.C.|Rochdale]] (loan) | caps6 = 12 | goals6 = 4 | years7 = 2007–2008 | clubs7 = [[Rochdale A.F.C.|Rochdale]] | caps7 = 42 | goals7 = 21 | years8 = 2008–2011 | clubs8 = [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] | caps8 = 118 | goals8 = 54 | years9 = 2011–2015 | clubs9 = [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] | caps9 = 112 | goals9 = 44 | years10 = 2014 | clubs10 = → [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] (loan) | caps10 = 18 | goals10 = 8 | years11 = 2015–2017 | clubs11 = [[AFC Bournemouth]] | caps11 = 19 | goals11 = 3 | years12 = 2016–2017 | clubs12 = → [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] (loan) | caps12 = 26 | goals12 = 15 | years13 = 2017– | clubs13 = [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] | caps13 = 82 | goals13 = 30 | nationalyears1 = | nationalteam1 = | nationalcaps1 = | nationalgoals1 = | club-update = 17:16, 2 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = }} '''Glenn Murray''' (born 25 September 1983) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[forward (association football)|striker]] for {{English football updater|Brigh&HA}} club [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]].
Prior to joining Brighton for a second spell in January 2017, Murray previously played for [[Workington A.F.C.|Workington Reds]], [[Wilmington Hammerheads FC|Wilmington Hammerheads]], [[Barrow A.F.C.|Barrow]], [[Carlisle United F.C.|Carlisle United]], [[Stockport County F.C.|Stockport County]], [[Rochdale A.F.C.|Rochdale]], [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]], [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] and [[AFC Bournemouth]].
He holds the record for most goals scored in a Championship season with 30 goals in the 2012–13 season.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.statbunker.com/alltimestats/MostGoalsScorerInSeason?comp_code=EC |title=Most goals in a season (Player) English Championship |website=Statbunker.com |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref>
==Career== ===Early career=== Born in [[Maryport]], Cumbria,<ref name=Hugman1011/> Murray began his playing career playing for non-League side [[Workington A.F.C.|Workington Reds]] before joining American team [[Wilmington Hammerheads FC|Wilmington Hammerheads]] in 2004. He spent one season with the [[North Carolina]] club playing 14 times and scoring three goals in the [[USL Professional League]].<ref name="Wilmington Hammerheads"/> After his time in America he joined [[Barrow A.F.C.|Barrow]] where he scored seven goals in seven games.<ref name="2004-05"/> Murray then signed for [[Conference Premier|Conference National]] side [[Carlisle United F.C.|Carlisle United]] and was part of the [[2005 Conference National play-off Final|Conference play-off]]-winning team in 2005 and [[Football League Two|League Two]]-winning side a season later.<ref name=2005PO>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_conf/4537061.stm |title=Stevenage 0–1 Carlisle |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 May 2005 |accessdate=3 December 2018}}</ref><ref name=Hugman0708>{{cite book |title=The PFA Footballers' Who's Who 2007–08 |editor-first=Barry J. |editor-last=Hugman |publisher=Mainstream |date=2007 |page=291 |isbn=978-1-84596-246-3}}</ref>
Murray joined [[Stockport County F.C.|Stockport County]] on loan for two months and he returned to Carlisle after this loan deal, following teammate [[Karl Hawley]]'s rib injury.
===Rochdale=== [[Rochdale A.F.C.|Rochdale]] manager [[Steve Parkin]] then signed Murray on loan until January 2007. Murray then signed for the club on a contract until 2009, for an undisclosed fee. He made his first start for Rochdale in their 7–1 defeat away at [[Lincoln City F.C.|Lincoln City]] on 21 October 2006. His first goal was a 59th-minute equaliser in their match with [[Barnet F.C.|Barnet]] on 18 November, but Rochdale lost the match 3–2. Murray made 31 league appearances in his first season with the club and scored 16 goals.
Murray made his first appearance for the 2007–08 season as a 53rd-minute substitute on the opening day in Rochdale's 3–0 loss away to [[Peterborough United]]. His first start of the season came in their 2–2 home draw with [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] in the first round of the [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] three days later on 14 August. Murray scored his first goal of the season in a 1–1 home draw with [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] in the League Cup second round, and his first league goal of the season came in Rochdale's 4–3 victory away at [[Shrewsbury Town F.C.|Shrewsbury Town]] on 29 September. He made 42 league appearances scoring 21 goals, giving him an average of one goal every two games in his Rochdale career.
===Brighton & Hove Albion=== [[File:Glenn Murray Brighton.jpg|thumb|150px|Murray playing for [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] in 2011]]
====2007–08 season==== Murray had been linked with a transfer to [[Football League One|League One]] team [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] throughout the January [[transfer window]], and finally completed his move to the [[Withdean Stadium]] on 25 January 2008 for a reported £300,000.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/1995123.albion_complete_murray_signing/ |title=Albion complete Murray signing |first=Andy |last=Naylor |newspaper=The Argus |location=Brighton |date=25 January 2008 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> He made his debut four days later, coming on as a 61st-minute substitute for [[Nathan Elder]] during the 1–0 defeat away to [[Northampton Town F.C.|Northampton Town]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.seagulls.co.uk.p.preprod.performgroup.com/page/MatchReport/0,,10433~39032,00.html |title=Northampton vs Brighton |first=Tim |last=Dudding |publisher=Brighton & Hove Albion F.C. |date=29 January 2008 |accessdate=7 April 2015}}</ref> He started Albion's next match, on 2 February at home to [[Crewe Alexandra]], and scored two goals on his home debut in the 3–0 victory.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.seagulls.premiumtv.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0,,10433~1231458,00.html |title=Brighton vs Crewe |first=Tim |last=Dudding |publisher=Brighton & Hove Albion F.C. |date=2 February 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080206134955/http://www.seagulls.premiumtv.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0,,10433~1231458,00.html |archivedate=6 February 2008}}</ref> Murray scored nine goals for Brighton during the 2007–08 season.
====2008–09 season==== Despite suffering several injuries during the 2008–09 season,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/3792312.albion-are-missing-murray/ |title=Albion are missing Murray |first=Andy |last=Naylor |newspaper=The Argus |location=Brighton |date=27 October 2008 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theargus.co.uk/sport/4140997.albion-striker-has-hernia-operation/ |title=Albion striker has hernia operation |first=Andy |last=Naylor |newspaper=The Argus |location=Brighton |date=20 February 2009 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> Murray made 28 appearances and scored 12 goals.<ref name=sb0809/> In the team's 4–0 win over Barnet in the first round of the League Cup on 12 August 2008, he was sent off.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/7541869.stm |title=Brighton 4–0 Barnet |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 August 2008 |accessdate=7 April 2015}}</ref> On 27 September, he netted twice in a 2–2 draw at Northampton Town; his second put the team ahead in added time before [[Adebayo Akinfenwa]] equalised.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/7626774.stm |title=Northampton 2–2 Brighton |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 September 2008 |accessdate=7 April 2015}}</ref> A week later he scored twice in the opening seven minutes and finished with his first [[hat-trick (association football)|hat-trick]] for the team in a 3–3 draw with [[Cheltenham Town]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/7639353.stm |title=Brighton 3–3 Cheltenham |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 October 2008 |accessdate=7 April 2015}}</ref>
====2009–10 season==== On 17 October 2009, Murray won and converted a penalty for a consolation goal in a 2–1 defeat at [[Tranmere Rovers]], but three minutes later was sent off for a second yellow card.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.skysports.com/football/tranmere-vs-brighton/report/110426 |title=Vital victory for Tranmere |publisher=Sky Sports |date=17 October 2009 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> He scored four times in Brighton's 5–2 win away at [[Wycombe Wanderers]] on 28 December, a result which moved Brighton out of the relegation zone.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/8419150.stm |title=Wycombe 2–5 Brighton |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 December 2009 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> Murray's season ended on 24 April 2010 with Brighton's 2–1 win over [[Bristol Rovers]] to stay in the division; he was sent off ten minutes after coming on as a substitute for [[Chris Holroyd]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/8620686.stm |title=Brighton 2–1 Bristol Rovers |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 April 2010 |accessdate=7 April 2015}}</ref>
====2010–11 season==== The 2010–11 season proved to be Murray's best season thus far at Brighton, scoring 22 goals and finishing runner-up to [[Craig Mackail-Smith]] as League One top scorer.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/page/DivisionalScorers/0,,10794~201025,00.html |title=Football League Statistics: 2010/11 npower Football League 1 Leading scorers |publisher=The Football League |accessdate=24 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140413202409/http://www.football-league.co.uk/page/DivisionalScorers/0,,10794~201025,00.html |archivedate=13 April 2014}}</ref> This included a hat-trick on 1 January 2011 in a 5–0 win over [[Leyton Orient]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/9310093.stm |title=Brighton 5–0 Leyton Orient |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 January 2011 |accessdate=7 April 2015}}</ref> On 20 May, the club confirmed that Murray had rejected their final offer of a new contract, so would be available on a free transfer when his contract expired.<ref name=L1Title1011>{{cite web |url=http://www.seagulls.co.uk/page/Latest/0,,10433~2363537,00.html |title=Murray's future lies away from Albion |first=Paul |last=Camillin |publisher=Brighton & Hove Albion F.C. |date=20 May 2011 |accessdate=24 May 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110523144920/http://www.seagulls.co.uk/page/Latest/0,,10433~2363537,00.html |archivedate=23 May 2011}}</ref>
===Crystal Palace=== [[File:Glenn Murray Crystal Palace.jpg|thumb|150px|left|Murray playing for [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] in 2012]]
====2011–12 season==== On 24 May 2011, Murray signed a three-year contract with [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]], [[M23 derby|Brighton's local rivals]]. Manager [[Dougie Freedman]] said that Murray was the type of player that his squad needed.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/crystal_palace/9495783.stm |title=Crystal Palace swoop for Brighton striker Glenn Murray |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 May 2011 |accessdate=7 April 2015}}</ref>
He made his debut{{snd}}his first match in the [[Football League Championship|Championship]]{{snd}}in the starting eleven as Palace began the season with a 2–1 loss at [[Peterborough United]] on 6 August.<ref name=sb1112/> He scored his first goal 21 days later, the equaliser in a 1–1 draw against [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] at [[Selhurst Park]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/aug/27/crystal-palace-blackpool-championship |title=Glenn Murray rescues a point for Crystal Palace against Blackpool |first=Jonny |last=Weeks |newspaper=The Observer |location=London |date=27 August 2011 |accessdate=7 April 2015}}</ref> On 27 September, he netted as Palace won 3–1 at his former club Brighton.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/14982392 |title=Brighton 1–3 Crystal Palace |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 September 2011 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> Murray scored the extra-time winner at [[Old Trafford]] against [[Manchester United]] in the League Cup quarter-finals on 30 November.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/15850177 |title=Manchester United 1–2 Crystal Palace |publisher=BBC Sport |date=30 November 2011 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref>
====2012–13 season==== On 22 September 2012, Murray scored a hat-trick including two penalties against [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]],<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/19614999 |title=Crystal Palace 3–2 Cardiff |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 September 2012 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> and repeated the feat on 6 November against [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] in a 5–0 victory despite missing a third penalty.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.skysports.com/football/c-palace-vs-ipswich/report/262516 |title=Ian Holloway in dreamland as Crystal Palace go top with 5–0 victory over Ipswich |publisher=Sky Sports |date=6 November 2012 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> He scored twice in a 3–0 home win over Brighton on 1 December, a result which put Palace on top of the league table.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.skysports.com/football/c-palace-vs-brighton/report/262399 |title=Glenn Murray scores twice as Crystal Palace beat Brighton 3–0 to return to top of Championship |publisher=Sky Sports |date=1 December 2012 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref>
On 2 February 2013, Murray scored twice in four minutes against South London rivals [[Charlton Athletic]] as Palace came from behind to win 2–1.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.skysports.com/football/c-palace-vs-charlton/report/262499 |title=Glenn Murray scored late double as Crystal Palace beat Charlton 2–1 |publisher=Sky Sports |date=2 February 2013 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> In March, he lost out to [[Watford F.C.|Watford]]'s [[Matěj Vydra]] as [[EFL Awards#2013 Awards|Championship Player of the Season]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/21922979 |title=Football League Awards: Matej Vydra named Player of the Year |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 March 2013 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> On 28 March, Murray signed a new three-year contract with Crystal Palace.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/21966635 |title=Glenn Murray: Crystal Palace striker agrees new contract |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 March 2013 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> Murray missed the [[2013 Football League Championship play-off Final|play-off final]], in which Palace secured promotion to the [[Premier League]], having suffered a serious knee injury in the semi-final against Brighton.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/football-league/crystal-palace-0-brighton-0-match-report-glenn-murray-injury-blow-as-palace-draw-a-blank-in-8611871.html |title=Crystal Palace 0 Brighton 0 match report: Glenn Murray injury blow as Palace draw a blank in Championship Play-off |first=Jack |last=Pitt-Brooke |newspaper=The Independent |location=London |date=11 May 2013 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref>
====2013–14 season==== Murray came back from injury as a 72nd-minute substitute for [[Jason Puncheon]] on 8 February 2014 in a 3–1 home win against [[West Bromwich Albion]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/feb/08/crystal-palace-west-bromwich-albion-premier-league-match-report |title=Crystal Palace new boy Tom Ince inspires victory over West Brom |newspaper=The Observer |location=London |agency=Press Association |date=8 February 2014 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> On 2 March, he scored his only goal of the season and his first in the Premier League, winning a late penalty against Swansea City after being fouled by [[Chico Flores]] and converting it past [[Michel Vorm]] to earn a 1–1 away draw.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/26311677 |title=Swansea City 1–1 Crystal Palace |first=Rob |last=Westall |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 March 2014 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref>
====2014–15 season==== ====Reading (loan)==== On 1 September 2014, transfer deadline day, Murray moved to Championship club [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] on loan until 1 January 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.readingfc.co.uk/news/2014/september/deadline-deal-striker-murray-signs-for-royals/ |title=Deadline deal: Striker Murray signs for Royals |publisher=Reading F.C. |date=1 September 2014 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> He scored twice in his debut match in a 3–0 win over Fulham.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/29091163 |title=Reading 3–0 Fulham |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 September 2014 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> Murray scored eight goals in 18 league games for Reading, ending on 26 December with a brace in a 2–2 draw at Brighton where he opened the scoring after 39 seconds.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.getreading.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/reading-fc-manager-steve-clarke-8349277 |title=Reading FC manager Steve Clarke content with a point after draw with Brighton & Hove Albion |first=Jonathan |last=Low |website=GetReading |date=27 December 2014 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref>
====Return to Palace==== At the end of January 2015, Murray signed a contract extension with Palace until 2017.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cpfc.co.uk/news/2015/january/murray-signs-contract-extension/ |title=Murray signs contract extension |publisher=Crystal Palace F.C. |date=30 January 2015 |accessdate=30 January 2015}}</ref> On 28 February, he scored twice and was sent off for two bookings as Palace won 3–1 away to West Ham United.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/31562853 |title=West Ham United 1–3 Crystal Palace |first=Simon |last=Stone |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 February 2015 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> Murray opened the scoring as Palace defeated reigning Premier League champions [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] 2–1 on 6 April.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/32111603 |title=Crystal Palace 2–1 Manchester City |first=Jonathan |last=Smith |publisher=BBC Sport |date=6 April 2015 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> Murray continued his goalscoring form by giving Palace a 1–0 lead in their 4–1 win at [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] on 11 April.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/32180018 |title=Sunderland 1–4 Crystal Palace |first=Michael |last=Emons |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 April 2015 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> Eight days later, Murray was selected in the [[Football League Awards#2015 Awards|Football Manager Team of the Decade]] at the [[Football League Awards]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.efl.com/news/2015/april/winners-announced-at-the-football-league-awards-2015/ |title=Winners announced at The Football League Awards 2015 |publisher=The Football League |date=20 April 2015 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> On 16 May against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], in [[Steven Gerrard]]'s final match at [[Anfield]], Murray's penalty was saved by [[Simon Mignolet]] but he hit in the rebound to confirm a 3–1 victory.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/32670817 |title=Liverpool 1–3 Crystal Palace |first=Phil |last=McNulty |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 May 2015 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref>
===AFC Bournemouth=== On 7 August 2015, Crystal Palace rejected a £3 million bid for Murray from Premier League rivals [[AFC Bournemouth]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/aug/07/crystal-palace-bournemouth-glenn-murray |title=Crystal Palace reject £3m bid from Bournemouth for Glenn Murray |first=Ed |last=Aarons |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=7 August 2015 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> On 1 September, an improved bid of £4 million was accepted, and Murray joined the club on a three-year-deal.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/34110604 |title=Glenn Murray: Bournemouth sign Crystal Palace striker for £4m |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 September 2015 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> He scored his first goal for Bournemouth on 3 October in a 1–1 draw with Watford, a fellow newly promoted team, but had a penalty saved late on.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/34366697 |title=AFC Bournemouth 1–1 Watford |first=Mandeep |last=Sanghera |publisher=BBC Sport |date=3 October 2015 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> He scored a consolation goal in the following match, a 5–1 loss at Manchester City.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/34493635 |title=Manchester City 5–1 AFC Bournemouth |first=Alistair |last=Magowan |publisher=BBC Sport |date=17 October 2015 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> In December, he scored a late headed goal to clinch a win against reigning champions [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/34951749 |title=Chelsea 0–1 AFC Bournemouth |first=Richard |last=Winton |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 December 2015 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref>
===Return to Brighton=== On 3 July 2016, Murray returned to Brighton & Hove Albion on a season-long loan.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.brightonandhovealbion.com/news/2016/july/murray-back-at-brighton/ |title=Murray back at Brighton |publisher=Brighton & Hove Albion F.C. |date=3 July 2016 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> His second debut for the Sussex side came on 6 August away to [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]], while his first goal in his second spell came at home to [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] six days later; he scored his second in the same match as Albion won 3–0.<ref name=sb1617/> Brighton repeated that scoreline at [[Falmer Stadium]] four days later against [[Rotherham United]], and Murray was again on the scoresheet.<ref name=sb1617/> On 29 October, Murray scored a hat-trick against Norwich City at Falmer as the Seagulls secured a 5–0 win,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.brightonandhovealbion.com/news/2016/october/albion-v-norwich/ |title=Albion v Norwich |first=James |last=Hilsum |publisher=Brighton & Hove Albion F.C. |date=29 October 2016 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> and on 18 November he scored his 150th career League goal in a 1–1 draw with [[Aston Villa]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/nov/18/brighton-aston-villa-championship-match-report |title=Glenn Murray landmark league strike earns Brighton point against Aston Villa |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |agency=Press Association |date=18 November 2016 |accessdate=18 November 2016}}</ref>
On 31 January 2017, Murray re-signed permanently for Brighton & Hove Albion on a deal until June 2019. He had scored 15 goals in 28 appearances while on loan to the club in the first half of the season.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/soccer-transfers/story/3050297/brighton-sign-glenn-murray-on-permanent-deal-from-bournemouth |title=Brighton sign Glenn Murray on permanent deal from Bournemouth |publisher=ESPN |agency=PA Sport |date=31 January 2017 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> He contributed 8 more league goals in the remainder of the season, including the opening goal in a 2–1 home win against [[Wigan Athletic]] on 17 April that sealed Brighton's promotion to the Premier League for the first time in their history.<ref name=sb1617/><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39549523 |title=Brighton & Hove Albion 2–1 Wigan Athletic |first=Gary |last=Smee |publisher=BBC Sport |date=17 April 2017 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref>
Newly promoted Brighton made a positive start to their inaugural Premier League season, sitting in 8th place after eleven games. An unbeaten run of four games from mid-October coincided with Murray hitting a good run of form, with the striker scoring four goals in the three games preceding the November international break. His scoring run began with two against West Ham United in a 3–0 away win, and he followed it up with goals against [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] at home and Swansea City away, earning Brighton four points.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/swansea-0-brighton-1-match-report-glenn-murray-goal-watch-replay-table-a8037831.html |title=Glenn Murray's goal-streak continues as Brighton battle past Swansea |first=Phil |last=Blanche |newspaper=The Independent |location=London |date=4 November 2017 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> On 8 January 2018, Murray scored the winning goal in Brighton's 2–1 victory over arch rivals and former club Crystal Palace to eliminate them from the [[FA Cup]] at the third-round stage.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/jan/08/brighton-hove-albion-crystal-palace-fa-cup-third-round-match-report |title=Glenn Murray leaves it late as Brighton knock Crystal Palace out of FA Cup |first=David |last=Hytner |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=8 January 2018 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref>
On 1 September 2018 Murray scored twice to take Brighton from 2–0 down to draw 2–2 with Fulham.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45305232 |title=Brighton & Hove Albion 2–2 Fulham |first=Steve |last=Sutcliffe |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 September 2018 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> His 100th goal for Albion, the only goal of the match at home to [[Wolverhampton Wanderers]] on 27 October, made him just the second man{{snd}}after [[Tommy Cook (sportsman)|Tommy Cook]] with 123{{snd}}to reach that milestone.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.brightonandhovealbion.com/matches/fixtures/first-team/2018192/october/brighton-and-hove-albion-vs-wolverhampton-wanderers-on-27-oct-18/ |title=Report: Albion 1 Wolves 0 |first=James |last=Hilsum |publisher=Brighton & Hove Albion F.C. |date=27 October 2018 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> After 9 games without scoring, on 29 January 2019 Murray scored another two goals against Fulham in a 4-2 away defeat. This time Fulham came back from 2 goals behind, and won.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46955255 |title=Fulham V Brighton & Hove Albion|publisher=BBC Sport |date=29 January 2019 |accessdate=29 January 2019}}</ref> On 6 February 2019 Murray scored another two goals this time coming off the bench in a fourth round FA Cup replay against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Brom]] where his goals put Brighton 2-1 and 3-1 up in the 3-1 victory.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/av/football/47151469|title=FA Cup: West Bromwich Albion 1-3 Brighton & Hove Albion highlights - BBC Sport|publisher=BBC Sport|date= 6 February 2019|accessdate= 6 February 2019}}</ref>
==Personal life== On 24 January 2018, Murray and his wife Stacey were arrested on suspicion of tax fraud totalling £1.1 million.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42809696 |title=Glenn Murray: Brighton striker arrested over £1.1m tax fraud |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 January 2018 |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2018/01/24/glenn-murray-wife-arrested-connection-suspected-11m-tax-fraud/ |title=Glenn Murray and wife arrested in connection with suspected £1.1m tax fraud |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=24 January 2018 |accessdate=25 January 2018}}</ref>
